question: Question_02_(b)
statement:
Consider the matrix

$A =\begin{bmatrix}
1& 2& 0& 3& 4 \\ 
2& 4& 3& 0& 5 \\ 
1& 2& -1& 5& 5 
\end{bmatrix}$

\textbf{(b)} Find a basis for the column space of \emph{A}.
sols:
From
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2006/Question_02_(a)}{part
(a)}, we found that

\[\text{rref}(A)=
\begin{bmatrix} 
1& 2& 0& 3& 4\\ 
0& 0& 1& -2& -1 \\ 
0& 0& 0& 0& 0
\end{bmatrix}\]

And from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2006/Question_02_(a)}{part
(a)}, we saw that only the column 1 and column 3 are pivot columns. Thus
column 1 and 3 of matrix \emph{A} are linearly independent and span
\emph{R(A)}. So a basis of \emph{R(A)} is given by

\[\left\{
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\ 
2\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}
0\\ 
3\\ 
-1
\end{bmatrix}\right\}\]
